item.title: Susan Blackmore: Memes and "temes"
item.description:
Susan Blackmore: Memes and "temes"

http://www.ted.com Susan Blackmore studies memes: ideas that replicate themselves from brain to brain like a virus. She makes a bold new argument: Humanity has spawned a new kind of meme, the teme, which spreads itself via technology -- and invents ways to keep itself alive

item.title: NAM (Non-Audible Murmur) Microphone from the Nara Institute of Science and Technology : DigInfo

item.title: NFC Passport Reader - Android Apps on Google Play
item.description:
NFC Passport Reader - Android Apps on Google Play

NFC Passport Reader reads and verifies embedded chips in electronic passports.

item.title: VR Interface Design Pre-Visualisation Methods
item.description:
VR Interface Design Pre-Visualisation Methods

Video References: http://aperturesciencellc.com/vr/references.pdf Corresponding Writeup: http://aperturesciencellc.com/vr/VisualDesignMethodsforVR_MikeAlger.pdf Previous Video: http://youtube.com/watch?v=n3b8hZ5NV2E Virtual reality provides new opportunities for user interactions with computer applications. The process of designing a comprehensive interaction paradigm will require a significant amount of consideration and development. My work outlines a few beginning design considerations related to zones for content, types of interaction, and interface design methods.

item.title: Magic Mirror on the Wall, "Is Pi or ESP, Fairest of All?"
item.description:
Magic Mirror on the Wall, "Is Pi or ESP, Fairest of All?"

"What's the weather like, honey?" "I don't know. Let me check the mirror." The mirror? Both [Dylan Pierce] and [Dani Eichorn] have mirror projects that display the weather. They took two different approaches which makes for an interesting comparison. [Dylan] uses a Rapsberry Pi with an actual monitor behind the mirror.

item.title: BIOWATCH |
item.description:
BIOWATCH |

BIOWATCH has developed a highly secure form of wearable authentication that is invisible to users.

item.title: thehumanweb/notes
item.description:
thehumanweb/notes

We believe that a number of industry disrupting technologies are at our doorstep, exciting technologies that will allow us to connect in more effective and meaningful ways. We believe that with this comes an opportunity to rethink our technological path, to examine our way of life, and what it means to be a human in the 21st century.
